entries.title: Promise
entries.excerpt: Promise A Promise is an object that represents a value that will exist in the future, but doesn't right now. Promises allow you to then attach callbacks that can run once the value becomes available (
entries.content: Promise A Promise is an object that represents a value that will exist in the future, but doesn't right now. Promises allow you to then attach callbacks that can run once the value becomes available (known as resolving), or if an error has occurred (known as rejecting). Summary Types Status Properties Status : Status Methods andThen (successHandler: (...: any) : ...any, failureHandler: (...: any) -> ...any) -> Promise <...any> andThenCall (callback: (...: any) : any, ...: any) -> Promise andThenReturn (...: any) : Promise await () : boolean, ...any awaitStatus () : Status, ...any cancel : () catch (failureHandler: (...: any) : ...any) -> Promise <...any> expect () : ...any finally (finallyHandler: (status: Status) : ...any) -> Promise <...any> finallyCall (callback: (...: any) : any, ...: any) -> Promise finallyReturn (...: any) : Promise getStatus () : Status now (rejectionValue?: any) : Promise tap (tapHandler: (...: any) : ...any) -> Promise <...any> timeout (seconds: number, rejectionValue: any) : Promise Functions all (promises: { Promise <T>}) : Promise <{T}> allSettled (promises: { Promise <T>}) : Promise <{Status}> any (promises: { Promise <T>}) : Promise <T> defer (executor: (resolve: (...: any) : (), reject: (...: any) -> (), onCancel: (abortHandler?: () -> ()) -> boolean) -> ()) -> Promise delay (seconds: number) : Promise <number> each (list: {T | Promise <T>}, predicate: (value: T, index: number) : U | Promise <U>) -> Promise <{U}> fold (list: {T | Promise <T>}, reducer: (accumulator: U, value: T, index: number) : U | Promise <U>, initialValue: U) fromEvent (event: Event, predicate: (...: P) : boolean) -> Promise <P> is (object: any) : boolean onUnhandledRejection (callback: (promise: Promise , ...: any)) : () -> () promisify (callback: (...: any) : ...any) -> (...: any) -> Promise race (promises: { Promise <T>}) : Promise <T> reject (...: any) : Promise <...any> resolve (...: any) : Promise <...any> retry (callback: (...: P) : Promise <T>, times: number, ...: P) -> Promise <T> retryWithDelay (callback: (...: P) : Promise <T>, times: number, seconds: number, ...: P) -> Promise <T> some (promises: { Promise <T>}, count: number) : Promise <{T}> try (callback: (...: T...) : ...any, ...: T...) -> Promise Types {#Types} Status {#Status} An enum value used to represent the Promise's status. enum Started : "Started" - The Promise is executing, and not settled yet. Resolved : "Resolved" - The Promise finished successfully. Rejected : "Rejected" - The Promise was rejected. Cancelled : "Cancelled" - The Promise was cancelled before it finished. Properties {#Properties} Status {#PromiseStatus} A table containing all members of the Status enum, e.g., Promise.Status.Resolved. enums Methods {#Methods} andThen {#andThen} Chains onto an existing Promise and returns a new Promise. :::warning Within the failure handler, you should never assume that the rejection value is a string. Some rejections within the Promise library are represented by [[Error]] objects. If you want to treat it as a string for debugging, you should call tostring on it first. ::: You can return a Promise from the success or failure handler and it will be chained onto. Calling andThen on a cancelled Promise returns a cancelled Promise. :::tip If the Promise returned by andThen is cancelled, successHandler and failureHandler will not run. To run code no matter what, use [Promise:finally]. ::: Parameters successHandler (...: any) -> ...any failureHandler (...: any) -> ...any Returns return Promise <...any> andThenCall {#andThenCall} Attaches an andThen handler to this Promise that calls the given callback with the predefined arguments. The resolved value is discarded. This is sugar for Parameters callback (...: any) -> any ... any Additional arguments which will be passed to callback Returns return Promise andThenReturn {#andThenReturn} Attaches an andThen handler to this Promise that discards the resolved value and returns the given value from it. This is sugar for :::caution Promises are eager, so if you pass a Promise to andThenReturn, it will begin executing before andThenReturn is reached in the chain. Likewise, if you pass a Promise created from [[Promise.reject]] into andThenReturn, it's possible that this will trigger the unhandled rejection warning. If you need to return a Promise, it's usually best practice to use [[Promise.andThen]]. ::: Parameters ... any Values to return from the function Returns return Promise await {#await} Yields the current thread until the given Promise completes. Returns true if the Promise resolved, followed by the values that the promise resolved or rejected with. :::caution If the Promise gets cancelled, this function will return false, which is indistinguishable from a rejection. If you need to differentiate, you should use [[Promise.awaitStatus]] instead. ::: Returns return boolean true if the Promise successfully resolved return ...any The values the Promise resolved or rejected with. awaitStatus {#awaitStatus} Yields the current thread until the given Promise completes. Returns the Promise's status, followed by the values that the promise resolved or rejected with. Returns return Status The Status representing the fate of the Promise return ...any The values the Promise resolved or rejected with. cancel {#cancel} Cancels this promise, preventing the promise from resolving or rejecting. Does not do anything if the promise is already settled. Cancellations will propagate upwards and downwards through chained promises. Promises will only be cancelled if all of their consumers are also cancelled. This is to say that if you call andThen twice on the same promise, and you cancel only one of the child promises, it will not cancel the parent promise until the other child promise is also cancelled. catch {#catch} Shorthand for Promise:andThen(nil, failureHandler). Returns a Promise that resolves if the failureHandler worked without encountering an additional error. :::warning Within the failure handler, you should never assume that the rejection value is a string. Some rejections within the Promise library are represented by [[Error]] objects. If you want to treat it as a string for debugging, you should call tostring on it first. ::: Calling catch on a cancelled Promise returns a cancelled Promise. :::tip If the Promise returned by catch is cancelled, failureHandler will not run. To run code no matter what, use [Promise:finally]. ::: Parameters failureHandler (...: any) -> ...any Returns return Promise <...any> expect {#expect} Yields the current thread until the given Promise completes. Returns the values that the promise resolved with. This is essentially sugar for: Errors if the Promise rejects or gets cancelled. Returns return ...any The values the Promise resolved with. Errors error any Errors with the rejection value if this Promise rejects or gets cancelled. finally {#finally} Set a handler that will be called regardless of the promise's fate. The handler is called when the promise is resolved, rejected, or cancelled. Returns a new Promise that: - resolves with the same values that this Promise resolves with. - rejects with the same values that this Promise rejects with. - is cancelled if this Promise is cancelled. If the value you return from the handler is a Promise: - We wait for the Promise to resolve, but we ultimately discard the resolved value. - If the returned Promise rejects, the Promise returned from finally will reject with the rejected value from the returned promise. - If the finally Promise is cancelled, and you returned a Promise from the handler, we cancel that Promise too. Otherwise, the return value from the finally handler is entirely discarded. :::note Cancellation As of Promise v4, Promise:finally does not count as a consumer of the parent Promise for cancellation purposes. This means that if all of a Promise's consumers are cancelled and the only remaining callbacks are finally handlers, the Promise is cancelled and the finally callbacks run then and there. Cancellation still propagates through the finally Promise though: if you cancel the finally Promise, it can cancel its parent Promise if it had no other consumers. Likewise, if the parent Promise is cancelled, the finally Promise will also be cancelled. ::: Parameters finallyHandler (status: Status) -> ...any Returns return Promise <...any> finallyCall {#finallyCall} Same as andThenCall, except for finally. Attaches a finally handler to this Promise that calls the given callback with the predefined arguments. Parameters callback (...: any) -> any ... any Additional arguments which will be passed to callback Returns return Promise finallyReturn {#finallyReturn} Attaches a finally handler to this Promise that discards the resolved value and returns the given value from it. This is sugar for Parameters ... any Values to return from the function Returns return Promise getStatus {#getStatus} Returns the current Promise status. Returns return Status now {#now} Chains a Promise from this one that is resolved if this Promise is already resolved, and rejected if it is not resolved at the time of calling :now(). This can be used to ensure your andThen handler occurs on the same frame as the root Promise execution. If this Promise is still running, Rejected, or Cancelled, the Promise returned from :now() will reject with the rejectionValue if passed, otherwise with a Promise.Error(Promise.Error.Kind.NotResolvedInTime). This can be checked with [[Error.isKind]]. Parameters rejectionValue? any The value to reject with if the Promise isn't resolved Returns return Promise tap {#tap} Similar to Promise.andThen, except the return value is the same as the value passed to the handler. In other words, you can insert a :tap into a Promise chain without affecting the value that downstream Promises receive. If you return a Promise from the tap handler callback, its value will be discarded but tap will still wait until it resolves before passing the original value through. Parameters tapHandler (...: any) -> ...any Returns return Promise <...any> timeout {#timeout} Returns a new Promise that resolves if the chained Promise resolves within seconds seconds, or rejects if execution time exceeds seconds. The chained Promise will be cancelled if the timeout is reached. Rejects with rejectionValue if it is non-nil. If a rejectionValue is not given, it will reject with a Promise.Error(Promise.Error.Kind.TimedOut). This can be checked with [[Error.isKind]]. Sugar for: Parameters seconds number rejectionValue any The value to reject with if the timeout is reached Returns return Promise Functions {#Functions} all {#all} Accepts an array of Promises and returns a new promise that: is resolved after all input promises resolve. is rejected if any input promises reject. :::info Only the first return value from each promise will be present in the resulting array. ::: After any input Promise rejects, all other input Promises that are still pending will be cancelled if they have no other consumers. Parameters promises { Promise <T>} Returns return Promise <{T}> allSettled {#allSettled} Accepts an array of Promises and returns a new Promise that resolves with an array of in-place Statuses when all input Promises have settled. This is equivalent to mapping promise:finally over the array of Promises. Parameters promises { Promise <T>} Returns return Promise <{Status}> any {#any} Accepts an array of Promises and returns a Promise that is resolved as soon as any of the input Promises resolves. It will reject only if all input Promises reject. As soon as one Promises resolves, all other pending Promises are cancelled if they have no other consumers. Resolves directly with the value of the first resolved Promise. This is essentially [[Promise.some]] with 1 count, except the Promise resolves with the value directly instead of an array with one element. Parameters promises { Promise <T>} Returns return Promise <T> defer {#defer} The same as Promise.new, except execution begins after the next Heartbeat event. This is a spiritual replacement for spawn, but it does not suffer from the same issues as spawn. Parameters executor (resolve: (...: any) -> (), reject: (...: any) -> (), onCancel: (abortHandler?: () -> ()) -> boolean) -> () Returns return Promise delay {#delay} Returns a Promise that resolves after seconds seconds have passed. The Promise resolves with the actual amount of time that was waited. This function is a wrapper around task.delay. :::warning Passing NaN, +Infinity, -Infinity, 0, or any other number less than the duration of a Heartbeat will cause the promise to resolve on the very next Heartbeat. ::: Parameters seconds number Returns return Promise <number> each {#each} Iterates serially over the given an array of values, calling the predicate callback on each value before continuing. If the predicate returns a Promise, we wait for that Promise to resolve before moving on to the next item in the array. :::info Promise.each is similar to Promise.all, except the Promises are ran in order instead of all at once. But because Promises are eager, by the time they are created, they're already running. Thus, we need a way to defer creation of each Promise until a later time. The predicate function exists as a way for us to operate on our data instead of creating a new closure for each Promise. If you would prefer, you can pass in an array of functions, and in the predicate, call the function and return its return value. ::: If the Promise a predicate returns rejects, the Promise from Promise.each is also rejected with the same value. If the array of values contains a Promise, when we get to that point in the list, we wait for the Promise to resolve before calling the predicate with the value. If a Promise in the array of values is already Rejected when Promise.each is called, Promise.each rejects with that value immediately (the predicate callback will never be called even once). If a Promise in the list is already Cancelled when Promise.each is called, Promise.each rejects with Promise.Error(Promise.Error.Kind.AlreadyCancelled). If a Promise in the array of values is Started at first, but later rejects, Promise.each will reject with that value and iteration will not continue once iteration encounters that value. Returns a Promise containing an array of the returned/resolved values from the predicate for each item in the array of values. If this Promise returned from Promise.each rejects or is cancelled for any reason, the following are true: - Iteration will not continue. - Any Promises within the array of values will now be cancelled if they have no other consumers. - The Promise returned from the currently active predicate will be cancelled if it hasn't resolved yet. Since 3.0.0 Parameters list {T | Promise <T>} predicate (value: T, index: number) -> U | Promise <U> Returns return Promise <{U}> fold {#fold} Folds an array of values or promises into a single value. The array is traversed sequentially. The reducer function can return a promise or value directly. Each iteration receives the resolved value from the previous, and the first receives your defined initial value. The folding will stop at the first rejection encountered. Since v3.1.0 Parameters list {T | Promise <T>} reducer (accumulator: U, value: T, index: number) -> U | Promise <U> initialValue U fromEvent {#fromEvent} Converts an event into a Promise which resolves the next time the event fires. The optional predicate callback, if passed, will receive the event arguments and should return true or false, based on if this fired event should resolve the Promise or not. If true, the Promise resolves. If false, nothing happens and the predicate will be rerun the next time the event fires. The Promise will resolve with the event arguments. :::tip This function will work given any object with a Connect method. This includes all Roblox events. ::: Since 3.0.0 Parameters event Event Any object with a Connect method. This includes all Roblox events. predicate (...: P) -> boolean A function which determines if the Promise should resolve with the given value, or wait for the next event to check again. Returns return Promise <P> is {#is} Checks whether the given object is a Promise via duck typing. This only checks if the object is a table and has an andThen method. Parameters object any Returns return boolean true if the given object is a Promise. onUnhandledRejection {#onUnhandledRejection} Registers a callback that runs when an unhandled rejection happens. An unhandled rejection happens when a Promise is rejected, and the rejection is not observed with :catch. The callback is called with the actual promise that rejected, followed by the rejection values. Since v3.2.0 Parameters callback (promise: Promise , ...: any) A callback that runs when an unhandled rejection happens. Returns return () -> () Function that unregisters the callback when called promisify {#promisify} Wraps a function that yields into one that returns a Promise. Any errors that occur while executing the function will be turned into rejections. :::info Promise.promisify is similar to Promise.try, except the callback is returned as a callable function instead of being invoked immediately. ::: Parameters callback (...: any) -> ...any Returns return (...: any) -> Promise race {#race} Accepts an array of Promises and returns a new promise that is resolved or rejected as soon as any Promise in the array resolves or rejects. :::warning If the first Promise to settle from the array settles with a rejection, the resulting Promise from race will reject. If you instead want to tolerate rejections, and only care about at least one Promise resolving, you should use Promise.any or Promise.some instead. ::: All other Promises that don't win the race will be cancelled if they have no other consumers. Parameters promises { Promise <T>} Returns return Promise <T> reject {#reject} Creates an immediately rejected Promise with the given value. :::caution Something needs to consume this rejection (i.e. :catch() it), otherwise it will emit an unhandled Promise rejection warning on the next frame. Thus, you should not create and store rejected Promises for later use. Only create them on-demand as needed. ::: Parameters ... any Returns return Promise <...any> resolve {#resolve} Creates an immediately resolved Promise with the given value. Parameters ... any Returns return Promise <...any> retry {#retry} Repeatedly calls a Promise-returning function up to times number of times, until the returned Promise resolves. If the amount of retries is exceeded, the function will return the latest rejected Promise. Since 3.0.0 Parameters callback (...: P) -> Promise <T> times number ... P Returns return Promise <T> retryWithDelay {#retryWithDelay} Repeatedly calls a Promise-returning function up to times number of times, waiting seconds seconds between each retry, until the returned Promise resolves. If the amount of retries is exceeded, the function will return the latest rejected Promise. Since v3.2.0 Parameters callback (...: P) -> Promise <T> times number seconds number ... P Returns return Promise <T> some {#some} Accepts an array of Promises and returns a Promise that is resolved as soon as count Promises are resolved from the input array. The resolved array values are in the order that the Promises resolved in. When this Promise resolves, all other pending Promises are cancelled if they have no other consumers. count 0 results in an empty array. The resultant array will never have more than count elements. Parameters promises { Promise <T>} count number Returns return Promise <{T}> try {#try} Begins a Promise chain, calling a function and returning a Promise resolving with its return value. If the function errors, the returned Promise will be rejected with the error. You can safely yield within the Promise.try callback. :::info Promise.try is similar to Promise.promisify, except the callback is invoked immediately instead of returning a new function. ::: Parameters callback (...: T...) -> ...any ... T... Additional arguments passed to callback Returns return Promise

entries.title: Promise
entries.excerpt: Engine Class Promise Class View Source A Promise is an object that represents a value that will exist in the future, but doesn't right now. Promises allow you to then attach callbacks that can run onc
entries.content: Engine Class Promise Class View Source A Promise is an object that represents a value that will exist in the future, but doesn't right now. Promises allow you to then attach callbacks that can run once the value becomes available (known as resolving), or if an error has occurred (known as rejecting). Summary Properties Status Status Methods timeout Promise getStatus Status andThen Promise<...any> catch Promise<...any> tap Promise<...any> andThenCall Promise andThenReturn Promise cancel void finally Promise<...any> finallyCall Promise finallyReturn Promise awaitStatus Status, ...any await boolean, ...any expect ...any now Promise Functions new Promise defer Promise resolve Promise<...any> reject Promise<...any> try Promise all Promise<{T}> fold void some Promise<{T}> any Promise<T> allSettled Promise<{Status}> race Promise<T> each Promise<{U}> is boolean promisify (...: any) -> Promise delay Promise<number> retry Promise<T> retryWithDelay Promise<T> fromEvent Promise<P> onUnhandledRejection () -> () Types Status type Properties Status Property Status View Source enums Promise.Status: Status A table containing all members of the Status enum, e.g., Promise.Status.Resolved. Methods timeout Method View Source Promise:timeout( seconds: number, rejectionValue?: any ) -> Promise Returns a new Promise that resolves if the chained Promise resolves within seconds seconds, or rejects if execution time exceeds seconds. The chained Promise will be cancelled if the timeout is reached. Rejects with rejectionValue if it is non-nil. If a rejectionValue is not given, it will reject with a Promise.Error(Promise.Error.Kind.TimedOut). This can be checked with [[Error.isKind]]. Sugar for: Parameters seconds number Type number rejectionValue? any The value to reject with if the timeout is reached Type any Returns Promise getStatus Method View Source Promise:getStatus() -> Status Returns the current Promise status. Returns Status andThen Method View Source Promise:andThen( successHandler: (...: any) -> ...any, failureHandler?: (...: any) -> ...any ) -> Promise<...any> Chains onto an existing Promise and returns a new Promise. :::warning Within the failure handler, you should never assume that the rejection value is a string. Some rejections within the Promise library are represented by [[Error]] objects. If you want to treat it as a string for debugging, you should call tostring on it first. ::: You can return a Promise from the success or failure handler and it will be chained onto. Calling andThen on a cancelled Promise returns a cancelled Promise. :::tip If the Promise returned by andThen is cancelled, successHandler and failureHandler will not run. To run code no matter what, use [Promise:finally]. ::: Parameters successHandler (...: any) -> ...any Type (...: any) -> ...any failureHandler? (...: any) -> ...any Type (...: any) -> ...any Returns Promise<...any> catch Method View Source Promise:catch( failureHandler: (...: any) -> ...any ) -> Promise<...any> Shorthand for Promise:andThen(nil, failureHandler). Returns a Promise that resolves if the failureHandler worked without encountering an additional error. :::warning Within the failure handler, you should never assume that the rejection value is a string. Some rejections within the Promise library are represented by [[Error]] objects. If you want to treat it as a string for debugging, you should call tostring on it first. ::: Calling catch on a cancelled Promise returns a cancelled Promise. :::tip If the Promise returned by catch is cancelled, failureHandler will not run. To run code no matter what, use [Promise:finally]. ::: Parameters failureHandler (...: any) -> ...any Type (...: any) -> ...any Returns Promise<...any> tap Method View Source Promise:tap( tapHandler: (...: any) -> ...any ) -> Promise<...any> Similar to Promise.andThen, except the return value is the same as the value passed to the handler. In other words, you can insert a :tap into a Promise chain without affecting the value that downstream Promises receive. If you return a Promise from the tap handler callback, its value will be discarded but tap will still wait until it resolves before passing the original value through. Parameters tapHandler (...: any) -> ...any Type (...: any) -> ...any Returns Promise<...any> andThenCall Method View Source Promise:andThenCall( callback: (...: any) -> any, ...?: any ) -> Promise Attaches an andThen handler to this Promise that calls the given callback with the predefined arguments. The resolved value is discarded. This is sugar for Parameters callback (...: any) -> any Type (...: any) -> any ...? any Additional arguments which will be passed to callback Type any Returns Promise andThenReturn Method View Source Promise:andThenReturn( ...: any ) -> Promise Attaches an andThen handler to this Promise that discards the resolved value and returns the given value from it. This is sugar for :::caution Promises are eager, so if you pass a Promise to andThenReturn, it will begin executing before andThenReturn is reached in the chain. Likewise, if you pass a Promise created from [[Promise.reject]] into andThenReturn, it's possible that this will trigger the unhandled rejection warning. If you need to return a Promise, it's usually best practice to use [[Promise.andThen]]. ::: Parameters ... any Values to return from the function Type any Returns Promise cancel Method View Source Promise:cancel() -> nil Cancels this promise, preventing the promise from resolving or rejecting. Does not do anything if the promise is already settled. Cancellations will propagate upwards and downwards through chained promises. Promises will only be cancelled if all of their consumers are also cancelled. This is to say that if you call andThen twice on the same promise, and you cancel only one of the child promises, it will not cancel the parent promise until the other child promise is also cancelled. finally Method View Source Promise:finally( finallyHandler: (status: Status) -> ...any ) -> Promise<...any> Set a handler that will be called regardless of the promise's fate. The handler is called when the promise is resolved, rejected, or cancelled. Returns a new Promise that: - resolves with the same values that this Promise resolves with. - rejects with the same values that this Promise rejects with. - is cancelled if this Promise is cancelled. If the value you return from the handler is a Promise: - We wait for the Promise to resolve, but we ultimately discard the resolved value. - If the returned Promise rejects, the Promise returned from finally will reject with the rejected value from the returned promise. - If the finally Promise is cancelled, and you returned a Promise from the handler, we cancel that Promise too. Otherwise, the return value from the finally handler is entirely discarded. :::note Cancellation As of Promise v4, Promise:finally does not count as a consumer of the parent Promise for cancellation purposes. This means that if all of a Promise's consumers are cancelled and the only remaining callbacks are finally handlers, the Promise is cancelled and the finally callbacks run then and there. Cancellation still propagates through the finally Promise though: if you cancel the finally Promise, it can cancel its parent Promise if it had no other consumers. Likewise, if the parent Promise is cancelled, the finally Promise will also be cancelled. ::: Parameters finallyHandler (status: Status) -> ...any Type (status: Status) -> ...any Returns Promise<...any> finallyCall Method View Source Promise:finallyCall( callback: (...: any) -> any, ...?: any ) -> Promise Same as andThenCall, except for finally. Attaches a finally handler to this Promise that calls the given callback with the predefined arguments. Parameters callback (...: any) -> any Type (...: any) -> any ...? any Additional arguments which will be passed to callback Type any Returns Promise finallyReturn Method View Source Promise:finallyReturn( ...: any ) -> Promise Attaches a finally handler to this Promise that discards the resolved value and returns the given value from it. This is sugar for Parameters ... any Values to return from the function Type any Returns Promise awaitStatus Method View Source Promise:awaitStatus() -> (Status, ...any) Yields the current thread until the given Promise completes. Returns the Promise's status, followed by the values that the promise resolved or rejected with. Returns Status The Status representing the fate of the Promise ...any The values the Promise resolved or rejected with. await Method View Source Promise:await() -> (boolean, ...any) Yields the current thread until the given Promise completes. Returns true if the Promise resolved, followed by the values that the promise resolved or rejected with. :::caution If the Promise gets cancelled, this function will return false, which is indistinguishable from a rejection. If you need to differentiate, you should use [[Promise.awaitStatus]] instead. ::: Returns boolean true if the Promise successfully resolved ...any The values the Promise resolved or rejected with. expect Method View Source Promise:expect() -> ...any Yields the current thread until the given Promise completes. Returns the values that the promise resolved with. This is essentially sugar for: Errors if the Promise rejects or gets cancelled. Returns ...any The values the Promise resolved with. Errors any Errors with the rejection value if this Promise rejects or gets cancelled. now Method View Source Promise:now( rejectionValue?: any ) -> Promise Chains a Promise from this one that is resolved if this Promise is already resolved, and rejected if it is not resolved at the time of calling :now(). This can be used to ensure your andThen handler occurs on the same frame as the root Promise execution. If this Promise is still running, Rejected, or Cancelled, the Promise returned from :now() will reject with the rejectionValue if passed, otherwise with a Promise.Error(Promise.Error.Kind.NotResolvedInTime). This can be checked with [[Error.isKind]]. Parameters rejectionValue? any The value to reject with if the Promise isn't resolved Type any Returns Promise Functions new Function View Source Promise.new( executor: (resolve: (...: any) -> (), reject: (...: any) -> (), onCancel: (abortHandler?: () -> ()) -> boolean) -> () ) -> Promise Construct a new Promise that will be resolved or rejected with the given callbacks. If you resolve with a Promise, it will be chained onto. You can safely yield within the executor function and it will not block the creating thread. You do not need to use pcall within a Promise. Errors that occur during execution will be caught and turned into a rejection automatically. If error() is called with a table, that table will be the rejection value. Otherwise, string errors will be converted into Promise.Error(Promise.Error.Kind.ExecutionError) objects for tracking debug information. You may register an optional cancellation hook by using the onCancel argument: This should be used to abort any ongoing operations leading up to the promise being settled. Call the onCancel function with a function callback as its only argument to set a hook which will in turn be called when/if the promise is cancelled. onCancel returns true if the Promise was already cancelled when you called onCancel. Calling onCancel with no argument will not override a previously set cancellation hook, but it will still return true if the Promise is currently cancelled. You can set the cancellation hook at any time before resolving. When a promise is cancelled, calls to resolve or reject will be ignored, regardless of if you set a cancellation hook or not. :::caution If the Promise is cancelled, the executor thread is closed with coroutine.close after the cancellation hook is called. You must perform any cleanup code in the cancellation hook: any time your executor yields, it may never resume. ::: Parameters executor (resolve: (...: any) -> (), reject: (...: any) -> (), onCancel: (abortHandler?: () -> ()) -> boolean) -> () Type (resolve: (...: any) -> (), reject: (...: any) -> (), onCancel: (abortHandler?: () -> ()) -> boolean) -> () Returns Promise defer Function View Source Promise.defer( executor: (resolve: (...: any) -> (), reject: (...: any) -> (), onCancel: (abortHandler?: () -> ()) -> boolean) -> () ) -> Promise The same as Promise.new, except execution begins after the next Heartbeat event. This is a spiritual replacement for spawn, but it does not suffer from the same issues as spawn. Parameters executor (resolve: (...: any) -> (), reject: (...: any) -> (), onCancel: (abortHandler?: () -> ()) -> boolean) -> () Type (resolve: (...: any) -> (), reject: (...: any) -> (), onCancel: (abortHandler?: () -> ()) -> boolean) -> () Returns Promise resolve Function View Source Promise.resolve( ...: any ) -> Promise<...any> Creates an immediately resolved Promise with the given value. Parameters ... any Type any Returns Promise<...any> reject Function View Source Promise.reject( ...: any ) -> Promise<...any> Creates an immediately rejected Promise with the given value. :::caution Something needs to consume this rejection (i.e. :catch() it), otherwise it will emit an unhandled Promise rejection warning on the next frame. Thus, you should not create and store rejected Promises for later use. Only create them on-demand as needed. ::: Parameters ... any Type any Returns Promise<...any> try Function View Source Promise.try( callback: (...: T...) -> ...any, ...: T... ) -> Promise Begins a Promise chain, calling a function and returning a Promise resolving with its return value. If the function errors, the returned Promise will be rejected with the error. You can safely yield within the Promise.try callback. :::info Promise.try is similar to Promise.promisify, except the callback is invoked immediately instead of returning a new function. ::: Parameters callback (...: T...) -> ...any Type (...: T...) -> ...any ... T... Additional arguments passed to callback Type T... Returns Promise all Function View Source Promise.all( promises: {Promise<T>} ) -> Promise<{T}> Accepts an array of Promises and returns a new promise that: is resolved after all input promises resolve. is rejected if any input promises reject. :::info Only the first return value from each promise will be present in the resulting array. ::: After any input Promise rejects, all other input Promises that are still pending will be cancelled if they have no other consumers. Parameters promises {Promise<T>} Type {Promise<T>} Returns Promise<{T}> fold Function View Source Promise.fold( list: {T | Promise<T>}, reducer: (accumulator: U, value: T, index: number) -> U | Promise<U>, initialValue: U ) -> nil Folds an array of values or promises into a single value. The array is traversed sequentially. The reducer function can return a promise or value directly. Each iteration receives the resolved value from the previous, and the first receives your defined initial value. The folding will stop at the first rejection encountered. Parameters list {T | Promise<T>} Type {T | Promise<T>} reducer (accumulator: U, value: T, index: number) -> U | Promise<U> Type (accumulator: U, value: T, index: number) -> U | Promise<U> initialValue U Type U some Function View Source Promise.some( promises: {Promise<T>}, count: number ) -> Promise<{T}> Accepts an array of Promises and returns a Promise that is resolved as soon as count Promises are resolved from the input array. The resolved array values are in the order that the Promises resolved in. When this Promise resolves, all other pending Promises are cancelled if they have no other consumers. count 0 results in an empty array. The resultant array will never have more than count elements. Parameters promises {Promise<T>} Type {Promise<T>} count number Type number Returns Promise<{T}> any Function View Source Promise.any( promises: {Promise<T>} ) -> Promise<T> Accepts an array of Promises and returns a Promise that is resolved as soon as any of the input Promises resolves. It will reject only if all input Promises reject. As soon as one Promises resolves, all other pending Promises are cancelled if they have no other consumers. Resolves directly with the value of the first resolved Promise. This is essentially [[Promise.some]] with 1 count, except the Promise resolves with the value directly instead of an array with one element. Parameters promises {Promise<T>} Type {Promise<T>} Returns Promise<T> allSettled Function View Source Promise.allSettled( promises: {Promise<T>} ) -> Promise<{Status}> Accepts an array of Promises and returns a new Promise that resolves with an array of in-place Statuses when all input Promises have settled. This is equivalent to mapping promise:finally over the array of Promises. Parameters promises {Promise<T>} Type {Promise<T>} Returns Promise<{Status}> race Function View Source Promise.race( promises: {Promise<T>} ) -> Promise<T> Accepts an array of Promises and returns a new promise that is resolved or rejected as soon as any Promise in the array resolves or rejects. :::warning If the first Promise to settle from the array settles with a rejection, the resulting Promise from race will reject. If you instead want to tolerate rejections, and only care about at least one Promise resolving, you should use Promise.any or Promise.some instead. ::: All other Promises that don't win the race will be cancelled if they have no other consumers. Parameters promises {Promise<T>} Type {Promise<T>} Returns Promise<T> each Function View Source Promise.each( list: {T | Promise<T>}, predicate: (value: T, index: number) -> U | Promise<U> ) -> Promise<{U}> Iterates serially over the given an array of values, calling the predicate callback on each value before continuing. If the predicate returns a Promise, we wait for that Promise to resolve before moving on to the next item in the array. :::info Promise.each is similar to Promise.all, except the Promises are ran in order instead of all at once. But because Promises are eager, by the time they are created, they're already running. Thus, we need a way to defer creation of each Promise until a later time. The predicate function exists as a way for us to operate on our data instead of creating a new closure for each Promise. If you would prefer, you can pass in an array of functions, and in the predicate, call the function and return its return value. ::: If the Promise a predicate returns rejects, the Promise from Promise.each is also rejected with the same value. If the array of values contains a Promise, when we get to that point in the list, we wait for the Promise to resolve before calling the predicate with the value. If a Promise in the array of values is already Rejected when Promise.each is called, Promise.each rejects with that value immediately (the predicate callback will never be called even once). If a Promise in the list is already Cancelled when Promise.each is called, Promise.each rejects with Promise.Error(Promise.Error.Kind.AlreadyCancelled). If a Promise in the array of values is Started at first, but later rejects, Promise.each will reject with that value and iteration will not continue once iteration encounters that value. Returns a Promise containing an array of the returned/resolved values from the predicate for each item in the array of values. If this Promise returned from Promise.each rejects or is cancelled for any reason, the following are true: - Iteration will not continue. - Any Promises within the array of values will now be cancelled if they have no other consumers. - The Promise returned from the currently active predicate will be cancelled if it hasn't resolved yet. Parameters list {T | Promise<T>} Type {T | Promise<T>} predicate (value: T, index: number) -> U | Promise<U> Type (value: T, index: number) -> U | Promise<U> Returns Promise<{U}> is Function View Source Promise.is( object: any ) -> boolean Checks whether the given object is a Promise via duck typing. This only checks if the object is a table and has an andThen method. Parameters object any Type any Returns boolean true if the given object is a Promise. promisify Function View Source Promise.promisify( callback: (...: any) -> ...any ) -> (...: any) -> Promise Wraps a function that yields into one that returns a Promise. Any errors that occur while executing the function will be turned into rejections. :::info Promise.promisify is similar to Promise.try, except the callback is returned as a callable function instead of being invoked immediately. ::: Parameters callback (...: any) -> ...any Type (...: any) -> ...any Returns (...: any) -> Promise delay Function View Source Promise.delay( seconds: number ) -> Promise<number> Returns a Promise that resolves after seconds seconds have passed. The Promise resolves with the actual amount of time that was waited. This function is a wrapper around task.delay. :::warning Passing NaN, +Infinity, -Infinity, 0, or any other number less than the duration of a Heartbeat will cause the promise to resolve on the very next Heartbeat. ::: Parameters seconds number Type number Returns Promise<number> retry Function View Source Promise.retry( callback: (...: P) -> Promise<T>, times: number, ...?: P ) -> Promise<T> Repeatedly calls a Promise-returning function up to times number of times, until the returned Promise resolves. If the amount of retries is exceeded, the function will return the latest rejected Promise. Parameters callback (...: P) -> Promise<T> Type (...: P) -> Promise<T> times number Type number ...? P Type P Returns Promise<T> retryWithDelay Function View Source Promise.retryWithDelay( callback: (...: P) -> Promise<T>, times: number, seconds: number, ...?: P ) -> Promise<T> Repeatedly calls a Promise-returning function up to times number of times, waiting seconds seconds between each retry, until the returned Promise resolves. If the amount of retries is exceeded, the function will return the latest rejected Promise. Parameters callback (...: P) -> Promise<T> Type (...: P) -> Promise<T> times number Type number seconds number Type number ...? P Type P Returns Promise<T> fromEvent Function View Source Promise.fromEvent( event: Event, predicate?: (...: P) -> boolean ) -> Promise<P> Converts an event into a Promise which resolves the next time the event fires. The optional predicate callback, if passed, will receive the event arguments and should return true or false, based on if this fired event should resolve the Promise or not. If true, the Promise resolves. If false, nothing happens and the predicate will be rerun the next time the event fires. The Promise will resolve with the event arguments. :::tip This function will work given any object with a Connect method. This includes all Roblox events. ::: Parameters event Event Any object with a Connect method. This includes all Roblox events. Type Event predicate? (...: P) -> boolean A function which determines if the Promise should resolve with the given value, or wait for the next event to check again. Type (...: P) -> boolean Returns Promise<P> onUnhandledRejection Function View Source Promise.onUnhandledRejection( callback: (promise: Promise, ...: any) ) -> () -> () Registers a callback that runs when an unhandled rejection happens. An unhandled rejection happens when a Promise is rejected, and the rejection is not observed with :catch. The callback is called with the actual promise that rejected, followed by the rejection values. Parameters callback (promise: Promise, ...: any) A callback that runs when an unhandled rejection happens. Type (promise: Promise, ...: any) Returns () -> () Function that unregisters the callback when called Types Status Type View Source An enum value used to represent the Promise's status.
